physDesc.p: Five pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "Aldington" in pencil at the top of first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: It was very nice of you to give us an opportunity to chip in a little bit. That is what I call being really friendly, and I am perfectly delighted that you should have written to me. It is a wonder to me that your remittances from home ever come, with the mails in the state they are, and there must have been lots of mail lost when the various vessels have been sunk. As a matter of fact, I had received a couple of days before Houghton Mifflin’s statement. We have sold 428 books, and the total amount of the sales amounts to $219.08, of which one-sixth is $36.51; therefore, I owe you and Richard $73.02. I added just a little to it to make it a round sum, as I thought that probably you were still stuck, as your letter only said that your remittances were coming, and coming is not come. Please do not think anything about it, and do not dream of paying it back. Take it as the most natural thing in the world, as I do. You see, my Dear Girl, I know what it is to have shattered nerves, I had nervous prostration for seven years once, and it is not a nice condition; so you just mustn’t have anything to worry about. Now if anything else happens of a like kind in future, just let me know, for I am most anxious to do everything I can for "the cause," and if you and Richard are not "the cause," I don’t know what is.

Lawrence has sent me some more poems, which he says come in the collection he left behind in Italy, and which has apparently just reached him. On the whole, Fletcher and I think three of them distinctly better than "Resurrection," and we have taken the liberty of substituting them for it. There is not time to send them over to you and get your consent to them, and it has worried me a good deal as to what to do on the subject, but finally both Fletcher and I agreed that the wisest thing to do was to calmly take them for the book, trusting to your approval of our choice. As you have left us the carte blanche to do what we wanted to with our own things, we thought this might extend to Lawrence’s poems as well. We were all so agreed on the subject of the badness of "Resurrection," or rather perhaps I should say its inadequacy and its inappropriateness to our volume, that I thought the others would be better than that anyway. Of course, in writing to Lawrence, I did not tell him my objections to "Resurrection;" I said all the nice things I could about it, and suppressed the others, as I did not like to hurt his feelings, but I am telling him now that we think these others that we have chosen are better for the book, and I am sure he will not object. I cannot even send you copies of them with this letter, because Lawrence asked me to see if I could find a publisher, and I took them in to Ferris Greenslet yesterday, with a view to his publishing them in the Autumn set of his New Poetry Series. He asked if he could keep them for a day or two, and entirely forgetting that I wanted to make copies for you, I left them with him, and he has gone off to Washington on business for a day or two, and I cannot possibly get hold of the poems until he comes back. This is excessively annoying, and I ought not to have done it; but as there would not be time to hear from you anyway, I hope you will forgive me, and I will send you the copies just as soon as I get them back.

The only thing that is delaying us now is my not having heard from you as to exactly which of the various selections of the poems we made you will agree to. I hope you understand that making this selection was merely a matter of space and nothing else. We can go to press with the poems, without waiting for the Preface, as soon as I hear from you.

I do wish there were any chance of getting you over here, for I am sure we should all have a splendid time living in the same town together. Fletcher is improving so much; he is much less nervous and seems to be very happy, and is writing busily all the time. He seems to like it here, and I am sure that you and Richard would like this town better than any other in America.

I am giving one of my talks at the Little Theatre in Chicago on <date when="1916-03-19>March 19th, and I am rather looking forward to it, as I should like to make some impression there. I think they are altogether too fond of Sandberg, and Masters, and Lindsay in Chicago.

Ferris Greenslet has made a ridiculous mess of his New Poetry Series by putting in anything and everything, utterly regardless of its fitness, with the result that the only volume of the Series which seems to be doing at all well is our Anthology. I think that has really done pretty well, and apparently it is still selling, for when I went in there yesterday they told me that they had just had to take over 85 more copies of the 220 copies of the second edition they had still unbound, and bind them – that since the first of January. I hope the next one will go as well.

I am adding a note to my "Stravinsky Cuartet"[sic] as follows: "This Quartet was played from the manuscript by the Flonzaley Quartet during their season of 1915 and 1916. The poem is based upon the programme which M. Stravinsky appended to his piece, and is an attempt to reproduce the sound and movement of the music as far as is possible in another medium." I think this would explain to people why the onomatopoetic lines are there, and that the poem is not intended as a joke or a take-off.

I have written to Harriet to say that I have here any of your poems which she desires. I am not altogether pleased with her attitude just now; there seems to be a great deal of Ezra in it, judging by the last number, although you will see that I did succeed in bullyragging her to put in Flint’s things in time for us to use them. I think the best way would be for me to see Harriet when I go out, and read her these things and try to get her to take them. I have always found that I could do more with her by personal contact than in any other way. I am delighted with the contents of the new book; I think it shows us all in advance of our last year’s work, and the bibliography shows an advance in the publications of the group.

Now, Hilda, don’t you think it would be a good idea if a book of yours came out in print? Have you got enough things to go in a book? I will do my best to force Ferris Greenslet to take it if you have. I hate to have you the only one of us who does not appear to have published a book, although for that very reason, the publishing of books seems futile.

I wonder why Richard feels as he does about "polyphonic prose." Last year, in his review of my book, he commended the metre as an interesting one, and said he had written several things in it, and recommended young poets to study it. Now he writes me that he does not like it, and the only things of mine he likes in it are the "Bombardment" and "Spring Day." That seems to me a very curious volte-face, and I cannot quite see why he takes it. Fletcher and I are devoted to the metre. We find it excellent for dramatic things. Perhaps the reason Richard does not care for it is because he writes very little dramatic poetry.
I am sending you an article in a Chicago monthly called the "Trimmed Lamp," which I think shows the way the wind is blowing.

Mrs. Aldis wanted to offer a prize for an Imagist poem, through the auspices of "The Little Review"; but her judges were very peculiar: they consisted of myself, Arthur Davidson Ficke, and John Powys. The whole thing seemed to me too absurd, and I disapprove of prizes anyway, on principle, they so seldom get awarded justly; though, as a matter of fact, I think when prizes are, and one cannot help it, it is a fine thing to win them. But to begin with prizes for Imagist poems when almost nobody knows how to write them, with myself as the only judge who knew what they were when written, would be too idiotic. Fletcher entirely agreed with me, and we have persuaded Mrs. Aldis to withdraw her suggestion – luckily, it had not got into print. Fletcher and I felt that as the only original group of Imagists could run in competition, we should be put into the curious position of half of us sitting in judgment of the other half, which seemed most unfortunate. I hope you will approve of my action.

If I do not hear from you in a couple of weeks, I shall just have to take the matter into my own hands and arrange your poems according to the group we most advised in our letter. Next year we must begin a great deal earlier with our Anthology, that is, unless the mails go more quickly.
Lots of love to you both, and don’t you let yourself get tired, Hilda, and don’t you worry about anything! Mrs. Russell joins me in sending much love.
